comments:
Trying to have a shared (i.e. in-project) shared configuration fails with a NPE if the project is on a non-local file system (see below).

The reason is that when moving an existing launch configuration, IWorkspaceRoot#findFilesForLocation is used, and that only works for the local file system.

This is a major issue for people providing alternative file system implementations as there is significant loss of functionality.

John/Rafael, how do we test an EFS?

That's a good question.  There are few sample EFS implementations that we have been using for testing:

In org.eclipse.core.tests.resources plugin there is an in-memory EFS implementation.  URI format is "mem:/path/to/resource".  This is good for automated JUnit testing.  We also have a "zip" file system implementation in the plugin org.eclipse.ui.examples.filesystem, but it currently has some bugs that are being worked out.

Rafael's case is actually simpler because it is an EFS that is simply a wrapper around the local file system.  This is different from other EFS's because, for example, IResource.getLocation() will still return the correct file system location.  I don't currently have such an example file system available for testing (I have entered bug 132345 for me to create one).  In the meantime, if you make a patch available Rafael may be able to verify it for you.

Rafael: it sounds like I would need to add a method FileStore.fromLocalFile to get find*ForLocation methods to work "for free" with a wrapper implementation. I have entered bug 132346 for this.

After some investigation to truely support alternate (non-wrapper) file systems we would need to change how the debug platform works with files completely, including how we interact with VMs, etc.

First step would be to change all file access to use IFileStore instead of java.io.File.

For 3.2 it is not viable to introduce this late in the game. Resolving it for later investigation, as alternate filesystem support would be a good feature.
